metadata.titleEn: 1 km grid datasets of human activity intensity in agricultural and pastoral areas of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau (1990-2020)
metadata.description: As the “third pole” of the world, the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau (QTP) is extremely ecologically sensitive and fragile while facing increasing human activities and overgrazing. In this study, eight types of spatial data were firstly selected, including grazing intensity, Night-Time Light, population density, Gross Domestic Product (GDP) density, the ratio of cultivated land, the slope of the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI), distance to road, and distance to town. Then, the entropy weight method was applied to determine the weight of each factor. Finally, the five-year interval human activity intensity data in 1990, 1995, 2000, 2005, 2010, 2015 and 2020 were made in the agricultural and pastoral areas of QTP through the spatial overlap method. By preparing the historical spatial datasets of human activity intensity, our study will help to explore the influence of human disturbance on the alpine ecosystems on the QTP and provide effective support for decision-making of government aiming at regional ecosystem management and sustainable development.
metadata.instructions: Each human activity intensity data stored in TIFF format, the name of the file as "yyyy. Tif", including yyyy on behalf of the year.Data read: can use ArcGIS, QGIS, ENVI, open and ERDAS software.

background: In remote sensing application research, nighttime light remote sensing has become an important and rapidly developing branch that has garnered increasing attention from both natural sciences and social economics in recent years. Unlike traditional optical remote sensing satellites that acquire radiation information of terrestrial objects, nighttime light remote sensing captures the visible light-near-infrared electromagnetic wave information emitted from the Earth's surface under cloud-free conditions at night. Compared to ordinary remote sensing satellite images, the nighttime light images record surface light intensity information that more directly reflects human activity differences, thus being widely applied in fields such as urbanization process research, impervious surface extraction, spatial estimation of socioeconomic indicators, major event assessment, and ecological environment evaluation. Benefiting from the capability of nighttime light remote sensing images for large-scale, long-term observation of the Earth, their open data products can effectively support research on human activities and urbanization processes. In recent years, with the continuous enrichment of light remote sensing data products, particularly the emergence of the new generation nighttime light data NPP/VIIRS (National Polar-Orbiting Partnership's Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite), the shortcomings of DMSP/OLS nighttime light data in terms of spatial resolution, temporal resolution, and radiometric resolution have been effectively addressed, greatly expanding the research directions and application fields of nighttime light data.
research objective: Based on this, the paper provides a detailed review of research findings related to nighttime light data over the past few decades, summarizing them from the perspectives of data processing and technical methods, as well as application research. Finally, the article identifies future research hotspots in three areas: multi-source data fusion, expansion of application fields, and short-term monitoring of surface lighting.
challenges: Currently, although the application research based on nighttime light data is continuously accumulating, there are still shortcomings in the systematic summary and organization of the results, such as incomplete coverage and lack of timeliness. Existing review papers on nighttime light data research also have shortcomings in terms of timeliness and coverage.

background: After the Industrial Revolution, which began in the UK in the latter half of the eighteenth century, energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions from fossil fuel consumption began to rise. As nations around the world started to develop their economies based on fossil fuel consumption, the stage was set for global warming and global environmental change. Electric power stations consume mostly fossil fuels and the night-time light emitted by human activity increases the consumption of electric power. Monitoring of electric power consumption and CO2 emission by a remote sensing device such as a satellite is an efficient method for observing at high resolution a wide area at a certain period of time.
research objective: A methodology is presented to accurately estimate electric power consumption from saturated night-time Defense Meteorological Satellite Program (DMSP) Operational Linescan System (OLS) imagery using a stable light correction.
challenges: Despite these advances, two problems remain to be solved in conventional studies: When constructing the dataset for extracting the stable light there are some arbitrary characteristics: (a) half-year data with a limited influence of the sunlight were used; and (b) the cloud cover was assessed visually, and images with only a few clouds were used. There are many studies about the relationship between the area of the stable light and electric power consumption as well as the CO2 emission but only a few of them deal with the cumulative DNs of the stable light parameter.
methods: An area correction for the stable light image of DMSP/OLS for the year 1999 was performed and the build-up area rate data were used to clarify the intensity distribution characteristics of the stable light. Based on the spatial distribution characteristics of the stable light, the saturation light of the electric power supply area of Japan was corrected using a cubic regression equation. The regression between the correction calculations by the cubic regression equation and the statistical electric power consumption data was applied in Japan and also in China, India and 10 other Asian countries.
dataset: In this study, we used DMSP-F14/OLS-VIS 1999 data from the Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries Satellite Image Database System (SIDaB) of the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries Agriculture Information Resources System (AGROPEDIA). The 1999 data for electric power consumption were obtained from the Statistics Bureau of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Japan (2002).
findings: This study confirms that electric power consumption can be estimated with high precision from the stable light.

background: Diabetes is one of the most common chronic non-communicable diseases among the older adults worldwide. The 2017 China Diabetes Prevalence Survey showed that the prevalence of diabetes in the older adults aged ≥ 60 years was 30.0%, and China has the largest number of older adults with diabetes in the world. Various acute and chronic complications caused by diabetes seriously affect the health status and quality of life of the older adults. Frailty, an emerging global health burden, is a common geriatric syndrome. A meta-analysis of 21 studies from Western high-income countries showed the prevalence of frailty among community-dwelling older adults ranges from 4 to 59%, with an average prevalence of 11%, the pooled prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty among community-dwelling older adults in China were 10 and 43%, respectively, leading to an increased risk of falls, disability, hospitalization, and death, as well as an independent predictor of higher healthcare expenditure among older adults. As populations age, diabetes and frailty are frequently co-occurring health outcomes, and both frailty and diabetes increase the risk of adverse outcomes in older adults. A meta-analysis showed that older adults with diabetes with frailty had significantly increased risks of hospitalization, disability, and death compared with older adults with diabetes who were not frail. Studies have shown that frailty was an important factor affecting the target level of blood glucose management in the older adults with diabetes. The International Position Statement on Frailty in Diabetes emphasized that the identification and assessment of frailty should be part of the routine management of people with diabetes. Compared with developed countries, the research on frailty in the older adults in China started relatively recently, there were few comprehensive studies on the prevalence and associated factors of frailty and pre-frailty among older adults with diabetes nationwide.
research objective: To investigate the prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty and its associated factors in Chinese older adults with diabetes through a nationwide cross-sectional study.
challenges: Our study has several limitations. First, the data on diabetes were self-reported and might be subject to memory bias. Second, this was a cross-sectional study, so the causal relationship between diabetes and frailty was not analyzed.
methods: The data were obtained from the Sample Survey of the Aged Population in Urban and Rural China (SSAPUR), conducted in 2015, which was a cross-sectional study involving a nationally representative sample of older adults aged 60 years or more from 31 provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities in mainland China. Subjects with diabetes were included in this study. Frailty index (FI), based on 33 potential deficits, was used to categorize individuals as robust, pre-frail, or frail.
dataset: The data were obtained from the Sample Survey of the Aged Population in Urban and Rural China (SSAPUR), conducted in 2015, which was a cross-sectional study involving a nationally representative sample of older adults aged 60 years or more from 31 provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities in mainland China.
findings: Our study found that frail patients with diabetes were older, were more likely to have been hospitalized in the past 1 year, were more likely to have ADL disability, and were more likely to have comorbidities than non-frail patients with diabetes. Our study also found that female, rural residency, illiterate, ethnic minority, widowed, living alone, financial difficulties, and very difficult medical reimbursement were associated with the prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty in older adults with diabetes. Our study found significant regional differences in the prevalence of frailty and pre-frailty in older adults with diabetes. The prevalence of frailty in older adults with diabetes in northern China was higher than that in southern China.

Concept Completion.Question: What factors are considered in assessing human activity intensity in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau agricultural and pastoral areas?
Concept Completion.Answer: grazing intensity, night-time light index, population density, GDP density, proportion of cultivated land, change rate of normalized vegetation index NDVI, distance to roads, distance to residential areas

Concept Completion.Question: Where can night-time light data be applied to better understand human activities?
Concept Completion.Answer: urbanization process studies, impervious surface extraction, spatial estimation of socioeconomic indicators, major events assessment, ecological environment evaluation

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a method used to determine the weight of factors affecting human activity intensity in agricultural and pastoral areas of the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: An example of a method used to determine the weight of factors affecting human activity intensity is the entropy weight method, which was utilized to assign weights to various factors such as grazing intensity, night-time light index, population density, and others in the dataset concerning the Tibetan Plateau.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset that could be used to study the relationship between night-time light emissions and human activity in large geographical areas?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset that is used to study the relationship between night-time light emissions and human activity is the DMSP/OLS night-time light data, which provides information on stable light emissions and is used to monitor electric power consumption and CO2 emissions in countries such as Japan, China, and India.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a challenge faced when using satellite-based night-time light data for assessing human activity levels?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge faced when using satellite-based night-time light data is the arbitrary characteristics in constructing the stable light dataset, such as dealing with cloud cover and the limited influence of sunlight, which can affect the accuracy of estimating electric power consumption and CO2 emissions.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific factors considered for assessing human activity intensity in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau agricultural and pastoral areas?
Feature Specification.Answer: grazing intensity, night-time light index, population density, GDP density, proportion of cultivated land, rate of change of the normalized difference vegetation index, distance to roads, distance to residential areas

Feature Specification.Question: What are the challenges in constructing datasets for stable light extraction in remote sensing studies?
Feature Specification.Answer: arbitrary characteristics, half-year data, limited sunlight influence, visually assessing cloud cover, minimal clouds, lack of comprehensive studies, cumulative digital numbers (DNs) of the stable light parameter

Quantification.Question: How many factors are considered in evaluating human activity intensity in the 青藏高原农牧区人类活动强度1km网格数据集?
What is the spatial resolution of the human activity intensity dataset for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?

Definition.Question: What is the entropy weight method in the context of evaluating human activity intensity?
Definition.Answer: The entropy weight method is a technique used to determine the weights of different factors when evaluating human activity intensity. In this context, it helps in assigning appropriate importance to various factors such as grazing intensity, night-time light index, population density, and GDP density, among others, to accurately assess the intensity of human activities in a given area.

Definition.Question: How is night-time light remote sensing utilized to monitor human activities?
Definition.Answer: Night-time light remote sensing is used to capture the visible light and near-infrared electromagnetic waves emitted from the Earth's surface during cloud-free nights. This method provides a direct measure of human activities by recording the intensity of surface lights, which can be utilized in studies of urbanization, impervious surface extraction, socioeconomic spatial estimation, and ecological environment assessments.

Definition.Question: What are some challenges associated with using night-time light data for research studies?
Definition.Answer: Challenges associated with using night-time light data include dealing with arbitrary characteristics when constructing stable light datasets, such as using half-year data with limited sunlight influence and visually assessing cloud cover. Additionally, there is a need for systematic summarization of research outcomes, as existing review papers may lack comprehensive coverage and timeliness.

Comparison.Question: How do the methods for estimating human activity intensity in the Tibetan Plateau using multiple factors compare to those using only night-time light data?
Comparison.Answer: The human activity intensity estimation for the Tibetan Plateau incorporates multiple factors such as grazing intensity, night-time light index, population density, and others, while using entropy weight method for factor weighting. In contrast, night-time light data alone primarily reflects human activity differences based on visible light emissions, which is more direct but less comprehensive compared to a multi-factor approach.

Interpretation.Question: How might the use of entropy weight method impact the interpretation of human activity intensity when integrating multiple factors such as population density, GDP density, and NDVI change rate?
Interpretation.Answer: The entropy weight method offers a systematic approach to determining the significance of each factor in assessing human activity intensity. By calculating weights based on the variability and importance of each factor, it allows for a more balanced interpretation of how different human activities contribute to overall intensity. This method helps in reducing subjective bias and provides a quantitative basis for understanding the relative impact of different activities.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of systematically summarizing and organizing results from night-time light data applications in ecological and socio-economic research?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges include the coverage of existing research being incomplete and lacking timeliness, as well as the limitations of review papers in terms of breadth and time relevance.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why are there difficulties in accurately estimating electric power consumption from night-time satellite imagery, such as the DMSP/OLS data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Difficulties arise from arbitrary dataset characteristics, such as using half-year data with minimal sunlight influence and visually assessing cloud cover, which can introduce inconsistencies in stable light extraction for power consumption estimation.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the prevalence of frailty among older adults with diabetes to vary regionally in China, and what factors are associated with these variations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The variations are caused by factors such as age, hospitalization history, ADL disability, comorbidities, gender, rural residency, literacy levels, ethnicity, marital status, living situation, financial status, and medical reimbursement difficulty, with significant regional differences noted between northern and southern China.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the entropy weight method affect the outcomes of assessing human activity intensity using various indicators?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The entropy weight method can provide a systematic approach to determine the weight of each indicator, which helps in producing a more balanced and accurate assessment of human activity intensity. This can improve the understanding of human impact on the ecosystems and support effective regional ecosystem management and sustainable development policies.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary goals of assessing human activity intensity in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau pastoral area using various factors such as grazing intensity and night-time light indices?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goals include exploring the impact of human disturbances on the alpine ecosystem of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau and providing effective support for government decision-making in regional ecosystem management and sustainable development.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to integrate multiple factors like GDP density, NDVI change rate, and proximity to roads when evaluating human activity intensity in ecologically sensitive regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Integrating multiple factors is important to comprehensively assess human activity intensity, capturing diverse dimensions of human influence on the environment, which aids in understanding and managing the ecological sensitivity and vulnerability of regions like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.

Goal Orientation.Question: What drives the necessity for utilizing entropy weight method in determining factor weights for spatial overlay analysis in human activity intensity assessments?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The necessity arises from the need to objectively determine the significance of each factor influencing human activity intensity, ensuring a balanced and data-driven approach to spatial analysis, which improves the accuracy and reliability of the resulting assessments.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What is the detailed process for determining the weights of factors when assessing human activity intensity in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau pastoral area?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The weights of factors for assessing human activity intensity in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau pastoral area are determined using the entropy weight method. This involves selecting eight factors, such as grazing intensity, night-time light index, population density, GDP density, proportion of cultivated land, NDVI change rate, distance to road, and distance to settlements, and then calculating their respective weights based on entropy.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is night-time light remote sensing utilized in evaluating human activities, and what are the challenges faced with this method?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Night-time light remote sensing is utilized by capturing visible light and near-infrared electromagnetic wave information emitted from the Earth's surface under cloud-free conditions at night. It provides a direct reflection of human activity differences and is widely used in urbanization studies and socioeconomic assessments. The challenges include the need for systematic summarization of study outcomes, issues with data coverage, and the limitations of conventional night-time light data in terms of temporal and spatial resolution.

Enablement.Question: What factors or methodologies enable the accurate assessment and weighting of human activity intensity in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau's agro-pastoral regions?
Enablement.Answer: The accurate assessment and weighting of human activity intensity in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau's agro-pastoral regions are enabled by selecting specific factors that reflect human activity intensity, such as grazing intensity, nighttime light index, population density, GDP density, cultivated land ratio, NDVI change rate, and distances to roads and settlements. Entropy weight method is used to determine the weight of each factor, and spatial overlay method is employed to compile the datasets for different years.

Enablement.Question: In what ways can the use of entropy weight method in determining factors' weights enhance the precision of human activity intensity datasets?
Enablement.Answer: The use of entropy weight method in determining factors' weights enhances the precision of human activity intensity datasets by objectively assigning weights based on the variability and significance of each factor. This method ensures that the contribution of each factor to human activity intensity is proportional to its impact, resulting in a more accurate representation of human activity intensity over time.

Expectation.Question: Why might the entropy weight method be expected to enhance the accuracy of human activity intensity assessments in regions like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: The entropy weight method is used to determine the weight of each factor reflecting human activity intensity, which can enhance the accuracy of assessments by objectively quantifying the contribution of variables such as grazing intensity, night-time light index, population density, GDP density, cultivated land ratio, NDVI change rate, and distances to roads and settlements.

Expectation.Question: Why could challenges arise from using night-time light data to assess human activity intensity, particularly in high-altitude regions like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges could arise due to limitations in spatial, temporal, and radiometric resolutions of older night-time light data like DMSP/OLS, although newer data like NPP/VIIRS have improved these aspects. The unique ecological and geographical conditions of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau may also affect the accuracy and applicability of night-time light data in capturing human activity.

Expectation.Question: Why might the integration of multiple data sources be crucial for understanding human impact on high-altitude ecosystems in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: Integrating multiple data sources allows for a comprehensive understanding of human impact on high-altitude ecosystems by combining diverse indicators such as economic activity, population density, and ecological changes. This multi-faceted approach helps address the complexity of human-environment interactions in sensitive and vulnerable regions like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.

Assertion.Question: I'm not clear on how datasets can accurately reflect the intensity of human activities in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau over time.
Assertion.Answer: The intensity of human activities is assessed by selecting eight factors, such as grazing intensity, night light index, population density, GDP density, arable land proportion, NDVI change rate, distance to roads, and distance to settlements. The entropy weighting method is used to determine the weight of each factor, and spatial overlay method is applied to obtain datasets for the years 1990, 1995, 2000, 2005, 2010, 2015, and 2020.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand the challenges involved in using night-time light data for assessing human activity.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges in using night-time light data include the need for systematic summarization of existing research findings, overcoming issues related to data coverage and timeliness, and addressing the limitations of previous studies, such as arbitrary characteristics in dataset construction and cloud cover assessment.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide a methodology for evaluating human activity intensity in a high-altitude ecosystem using remote sensing data.
Request/Directive.Answer: In evaluating human activity intensity in a high-altitude ecosystem, entropy weight method can be used to determine the weights of various factors like grazing intensity, night-time light index, population density, GDP density, cultivated land ratio, NDVI change rate, distance to roads, and distance to settlements. These factors are then spatially overlaid to generate datasets for multiple years, allowing for an assessment of human impact over time.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe a systematic approach to integrating multiple data sources for assessing socio-economic impacts in ecologically sensitive regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: A systematic approach involves integrating multiple data sources such as night-time light remote sensing data, demographic statistics, economic data, and ecological indicators. Techniques like multi-source data fusion and spatial overlay can be employed to enhance the granularity and accuracy of socio-economic impact assessments. Such integration helps in comprehensively evaluating human activities and their effects on ecologically sensitive regions.
